intro: Zornia reptans, commonly known as the creeping zornia, is a low-growing annual plant native to the United States. It belongs to the Leguminosae family and is characterized by its prostrate or ascending habit, with small, trifoliate leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-white flowers that are clustered in dense spikes, and it is often found in disturbed soils such as roadsides and fields. Zornia reptans has a fibrous root system and is adapted to thrive in dry, sandy environments. It is also known for its ability to fix nitrogen, making it a valuable plant in certain ecological contexts.
